001// Copyright (c) FIRST and other WPILib contributors.
002// Open Source Software; you can modify and/or share it under the terms of
003// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.
004
005package edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command;
006
007import java.util.Set;
008import java.util.function.BooleanSupplier;
009
010/**
011 * A state machine representing a complete action to be performed by the robot. Commands are run by
012 * the {@link CommandScheduler}, and can be composed into CommandGroups to allow users to build
013 * complicated multi-step actions without the need to roll the state machine logic themselves.
014 *
015 * <p>Commands are run synchronously from the main robot loop; no multithreading is used, unless
016 * specified explicitly from the command implementation.
017 *
018 * <p>This class is provided by the NewCommands VendorDep
019 */
020public interface Command {
021  /** The initial subroutine of a command. Called once when the command is initially scheduled. */
022  default void initialize() {}
023
024  /** The main body of a command. Called repeatedly while the command is scheduled. */
025  default void execute() {}
026
027  /**
028   * The action to take when the command ends. Called when either the command finishes normally, or
029   * when it interrupted/canceled.
030   *
031   * <p>Do not schedule commands here that share requirements with this command. Use {@link
032   * #andThen(Command...)} instead.
033   *
034   * @param interrupted whether the command was interrupted/canceled
035   */
036  default void end(boolean interrupted) {}
037
038  /**
039   * Whether the command has finished. Once a command finishes, the scheduler will call its end()
040   * method and un-schedule it.
041   *
042   * @return whether the command has finished.
043   */
044  default boolean isFinished() {
045    return false;
046  }
047
048  /**
049   * Specifies the set of subsystems used by this command. Two commands cannot use the same
050   * subsystem at the same time. If the command is scheduled as interruptible and another command is
051   * scheduled that shares a requirement, the command will be interrupted. Else, the command will
052   * not be scheduled. If no subsystems are required, return an empty set.
053   *
054   * <p>Note: it is recommended that user implementations contain the requirements as a field, and
055   * return that field here, rather than allocating a new set every time this is called.
056   *
057   * @return the set of subsystems that are required
058   */
059  Set<Subsystem> getRequirements();
060
061  /**
062   * Decorates this command with a timeout. If the specified timeout is exceeded before the command
063   * finishes normally, the command will be interrupted and un-scheduled. Note that the timeout only
064   * applies to the command returned by this method; the calling command is not itself changed.
065   *
066   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
067   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
068   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
069   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
070   * decorated without issue.
071   *
072   * @param seconds the timeout duration
073   * @return the command with the timeout added
074   */
075  default ParallelRaceGroup withTimeout(double seconds) {
076    return raceWith(new WaitCommand(seconds));
077  }
078
079  /**
080   * Decorates this command with an interrupt condition. If the specified condition becomes true
081   * before the command finishes normally, the command will be interrupted and un-scheduled. Note
082   * that this only applies to the command returned by this method; the calling command is not
083   * itself changed.
084   *
085   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
086   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
087   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
088   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
089   * decorated without issue.
090   *
091   * @param condition the interrupt condition
092   * @return the command with the interrupt condition added
093   */
094  default ParallelRaceGroup until(BooleanSupplier condition) {
095    return raceWith(new WaitUntilCommand(condition));
096  }
097
098  /**
099   * Decorates this command with an interrupt condition. If the specified condition becomes true
100   * before the command finishes normally, the command will be interrupted and un-scheduled. Note
101   * that this only applies to the command returned by this method; the calling command is not
102   * itself changed.
103   *
104   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
105   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
106   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
107   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
108   * decorated without issue.
109   *
110   * @param condition the interrupt condition
111   * @return the command with the interrupt condition added
112   */
113  default ParallelRaceGroup withInterrupt(BooleanSupplier condition) {
114    return until(condition);
115  }
116
117  /**
118   * Decorates this command with a runnable to run before this command starts.
119   *
120   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
121   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
122   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
123   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
124   * decorated without issue.
125   *
126   * @param toRun the Runnable to run
127   * @param requirements the required subsystems
128   * @return the decorated command
129   */
130  default SequentialCommandGroup beforeStarting(Runnable toRun, Subsystem... requirements) {
131    return beforeStarting(new InstantCommand(toRun, requirements));
132  }
133
134  /**
135   * Decorates this command with another command to run before this command starts.
136   *
137   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
138   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
139   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
140   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
141   * decorated without issue.
142   *
143   * @param before the command to run before this one
144   * @return the decorated command
145   */
146  default SequentialCommandGroup beforeStarting(Command before) {
147    return new SequentialCommandGroup(before, this);
148  }
149
150  /**
151   * Decorates this command with a runnable to run after the command finishes.
152   *
153   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
154   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
155   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
156   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
157   * decorated without issue.
158   *
159   * @param toRun the Runnable to run
160   * @param requirements the required subsystems
161   * @return the decorated command
162   */
163  default SequentialCommandGroup andThen(Runnable toRun, Subsystem... requirements) {
164    return andThen(new InstantCommand(toRun, requirements));
165  }
166
167  /**
168   * Decorates this command with a set of commands to run after it in sequence. Often more
169   * convenient/less-verbose than constructing a new {@link SequentialCommandGroup} explicitly.
170   *
171   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
172   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
173   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
174   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
175   * decorated without issue.
176   *
177   * @param next the commands to run next
178   * @return the decorated command
179   */
180  default SequentialCommandGroup andThen(Command... next) {
181    SequentialCommandGroup group = new SequentialCommandGroup(this);
182    group.addCommands(next);
183    return group;
184  }
185
186  /**
187   * Decorates this command with a set of commands to run parallel to it, ending when the calling
188   * command ends and interrupting all the others. Often more convenient/less-verbose than
189   * constructing a new {@link ParallelDeadlineGroup} explicitly.
190   *
191   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
192   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
193   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
194   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
195   * decorated without issue.
196   *
197   * @param parallel the commands to run in parallel
198   * @return the decorated command
199   */
200  default ParallelDeadlineGroup deadlineWith(Command... parallel) {
201    return new ParallelDeadlineGroup(this, parallel);
202  }
203
204  /**
205   * Decorates this command with a set of commands to run parallel to it, ending when the last
206   * command ends. Often more convenient/less-verbose than constructing a new {@link
207   * ParallelCommandGroup} explicitly.
208   *
209   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
210   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
211   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
212   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
213   * decorated without issue.
214   *
215   * @param parallel the commands to run in parallel
216   * @return the decorated command
217   */
218  default ParallelCommandGroup alongWith(Command... parallel) {
219    ParallelCommandGroup group = new ParallelCommandGroup(this);
220    group.addCommands(parallel);
221    return group;
222  }
223
224  /**
225   * Decorates this command with a set of commands to run parallel to it, ending when the first
226   * command ends. Often more convenient/less-verbose than constructing a new {@link
227   * ParallelRaceGroup} explicitly.
228   *
229   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
230   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
231   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
232   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
233   * decorated without issue.
234   *
235   * @param parallel the commands to run in parallel
236   * @return the decorated command
237   */
238  default ParallelRaceGroup raceWith(Command... parallel) {
239    ParallelRaceGroup group = new ParallelRaceGroup(this);
240    group.addCommands(parallel);
241    return group;
242  }
243
244  /**
245   * Decorates this command to run perpetually, ignoring its ordinary end conditions. The decorated
246   * command can still be interrupted or canceled.
247   *
248   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
249   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
250   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
251   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
252   * decorated without issue.
253   *
254   * @return the decorated command
255   * @deprecated use {@link #endlessly()} instead.
256   */
257  @SuppressWarnings("removal") // PerpetualCommand
258  @Deprecated(forRemoval = true, since = "2023")
259  default PerpetualCommand perpetually() {
260    return new PerpetualCommand(this);
261  }
262
263  /**
264   * Decorates this command to run endlessly, ignoring its ordinary end conditions. The decorated
265   * command can still be interrupted or canceled.
266   *
267   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
268   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
269   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
270   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
271   * decorated without issue.
272   *
273   * @return the decorated command
274   */
275  default EndlessCommand endlessly() {
276    return new EndlessCommand(this);
277  }
278
279  /**
280   * Decorates this command to run repeatedly, restarting it when it ends, until this command is
281   * interrupted. The decorated command can still be canceled.
282   *
283   * <p>Note: This decorator works by composing this command within a CommandGroup. The command
284   * cannot be used independently after being decorated, or be re-decorated with a different
285   * decorator, unless it is manually cleared from the list of grouped commands with {@link
286   * CommandGroupBase#clearGroupedCommand(Command)}. The decorated command can, however, be further
287   * decorated without issue.
288   *
289   * @return the decorated command
290   */
291  default RepeatCommand repeat() {
292    return new RepeatCommand(this);
293  }
294
295  /**
296   * Decorates this command to run "by proxy" by wrapping it in a {@link ProxyScheduleCommand}. This
297   * is useful for "forking off" from command groups when the user does not wish to extend the
298   * command's requirements to the entire command group.
299   *
300   * @return the decorated command
301   */
302  default ProxyScheduleCommand asProxy() {
303    return new ProxyScheduleCommand(this);
304  }
305
306  /**
307   * Decorates this command to only run if this condition is not met. If the command is already
308   * running and the condition changes to true, the command will not stop running. The requirements
309   * of this command will be kept for the new conditonal command.
310   *
311   * @param condition the condition that will prevent the command from running
312   * @return the decorated command
313   */
314  default ConditionalCommand unless(BooleanSupplier condition) {
315    return new ConditionalCommand(new InstantCommand(), this, condition);
316  }
317
318  /**
319   * Schedules this command.
320   *
321   * @param interruptible whether this command can be interrupted by another command that shares one
322   *     of its requirements
323   */
324  default void schedule(boolean interruptible) {
325    CommandScheduler.getInstance().schedule(interruptible, this);
326  }
327
328  /** Schedules this command, defaulting to interruptible. */
329  default void schedule() {
330    schedule(true);
331  }
332
333  /**
334   * Cancels this command. Will call the command's end() method with interrupted=true. Commands will
335   * be canceled even if they are not marked as interruptible.
336   */
337  default void cancel() {
338    CommandScheduler.getInstance().cancel(this);
339  }
340
341  /**
342   * Whether or not the command is currently scheduled. Note that this does not detect whether the
343   * command is being run by a CommandGroup, only whether it is directly being run by the scheduler.
344   *
345   * @return Whether the command is scheduled.
346   */
347  default boolean isScheduled() {
348    return CommandScheduler.getInstance().isScheduled(this);
349  }
350
351  /**
352   * Whether the command requires a given subsystem.
353   *
354   * @param requirement the subsystem to inquire about
355   * @return whether the subsystem is required
356   */
357  default boolean hasRequirement(Subsystem requirement) {
358    return getRequirements().contains(requirement);
359  }
360
361  /**
362   * Whether the given command should run when the robot is disabled. Override to return true if the
363   * command should run when disabled.
364   *
365   * @return whether the command should run when the robot is disabled
366   */
367  default boolean runsWhenDisabled() {
368    return false;
369  }
370
371  /**
372   * Gets the name of this Command.
373   *
374   * @return Name
375   */
376  default String getName() {
377    return this.getClass().getSimpleName();
378  }
379}
